educated. Today, students have replaced this eagerness by

grades. This new attitude makes for scholarly work that is
admirable, but work for a different reason. At one time,
the education itself was most important. Now, the grades
received while being educated are of primary concern.
This new attitude was caused in many ways by the
students themselves, but other factors have also made for
the change. The greatest cause of this change came from
the graduate institutions requirement of near perfection
for admittance. A student cannot help but be affected by
this dread of rejection at such an early stage in life. Yet
Still, the students themselves further alter the past
educational philosophy. Students make course selections
often solely on the ease with which one can receive an A.
Students avoid courses that might well interest tilem, and
the student's own new attitudes has drawn him away

decade ago, but the improvement ofthe mind still
motivated students to lear . Today's student often ends
four years of undergraduate study with a dark future
ahead, even after studying hard. We cannot change the
bitter competition wat admission to graduate school
brings out, but perhaps a student's ideals of success can be
reevaluated. Success doesnot have to be measured by the
A's received so that one can be admitted to graduate
school, but by the knowledge an undergraduate has
gained. In other words, what students of a decade ago
took for granted; that is, eagerness, fervor, and a desire to

To the Editor: The Board of Intramural Athletics
takes great exception to the accusations perpetrated in
last Friday's Editorial and Letter to the Editor. The
claims of discrimination against females are just as
Preposterous now as they were four years ago, when
women first applied and were accepted onto the BIA,
which was before varsity women's sports ever existed. It is
unfortunate that the editorial staff chose to indulge again

parroting the cornplaints of one
mis-informed
individual about the program that involves more students

record straight point by point.

currently no BIA sports for women," it sliould be noted
that EVERY intramural event, with the possible
exception of wrestling, is open to coed participation. This
is explicitly stated in the BIA Bylaws as well as the rules

addition, all publicity announcements include the
statement-open to all undergraduates.

yes. In fact, coed volleyball failed during last term

two-girl per team requirement. As far as tile freshmen are
concerned, the housemasters and the athletic reps of all
dorms, including Adams and Baker, nave gotten every
announcement and scandal sheet in their mailboxes and

have a physical or ability disadvantage. For this reason, it
was quite disappointing that when a special survey was
made last fall to determine interest in :gymnastics, a sport
in which women usually excel, only two responses were
received. Only last year there was a soccer team entered
that was composed entirely of women.

students to participate. It cannot go out recruiting people
all the time to form teams. By way of example, graduate
students are generally excluded from BIA events because
of age and skill differences. This year, many grad students

working relations with the Coordinator of Women's
Athletics.

others to participate.

members." Out of 13 applicants to next year's BIA, four
